Nashville — Shownotes S01E04

By:   |  Mailed on: November 05, 2012

Dear , ,

Dear Cast and Crew of Nashville, S1E04 – “We Live in Two Different Worlds”

Episode synopsis:
The arrival of a woman from Teddy’s past tests his marriage; Rayna and Deacon perform at Teddy’s fundraiser; Juliette appears on “Good Morning America;” and Gunnar connects with his publisher’s assistant.

Original air date:
October 31, 2012

Shownotes:

  • Oh-no-you-di-in’t just hook-up, Rayna and Deacon! Oh, no, you didn’t. (Dream sequence, false sass-alarm).
  • I want whatever cell phone camera was used to capture Juliette’s shoplifting with such beautiful depth of field. And fake scan lines.
  • Diss! Scarlett skillfully dodged Gunner to land that celebratory record deal hug on Avery.
  • Rayan’s sister is the “mouth of the south”? But she’s not even a singer!
  • Apparently, Rayna’s list of worse places to sing (in order): Airport. Mars. Hell. Connecticut. And THEN a country club?
  • Juliette on her knees in the back of a car is not as sexy as I had imagined.
  • Gunner’s metaphor for his own sex-life is a kayak. What about the others? I say Rayna’s a twin engine, Juliette’s a whaler, and Lamar is definitely a Cleveland Steamer.
  • Teddy’s ill-timed tick to scratch his neck is very telling he had an affair. And probably an STI.
  • Juliette’s using her Twitter account. Remind me to cross-reference that I’m writing to the right one.
  • Juliette just furiously emptied her mom’s bag, and then emptied her heart. Okay, so the girl can act.
  • Charles Esten has visibly aged since his days as an improv comic. Whose lines are they, anyway? The ones on his face. They look good on him.  
  • So new childhood trauma: Rayna’s elementary school classmates made fun of her for liking country music. In Nashville. Uh huh.
  • Finally, a song! It only took ¾ of the show to get to. Wasn’t worth the wait.
  • Personalized guitar straps are like the punk rock of country music. You go, Deacon!
  • Where is this alt-rock “Ammunition” song coming from?

Closing comments: I needed a cold shower after this episode. Not because it starts off with a sexual fantasy and ends with a one-night stand, but because it was so damn soapy. With all these scandals and heartaches brewing, it could spell the beginning of the show’s Glee-ful demise if they can’t harness these inspirations into a country music goldmine.

Signed,

Christopher Redmond
